title: How to Make Lasagna with Eggplant Instead of Noodles

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and slice the eggplants.
steps.description:
Turn the oven on to 400 °F (204 °C). Wash 3 medium eggplants and trim off 1-inch (2.5 cm) the ends. Hold each eggplant steady with one hand and use a knife to slice long 1/4-inch (6 mm) slices. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0e\/Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg\/v4-190px-Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":"190","bigHeight":"127","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} 1 medium eggplant weighs around 1 pound (453 g).

steps.headline: Salt and rest the eggplant for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Lay the eggplant slices on a baking sheet in a single layer. Sprinkle a large pinch of kosher salt evenly over the slices and let the eggplant rest for 20 minutes. Salting the eggplant draws out excess moisture which will prevent your lasagna from becoming soggy as it bakes.

steps.headline: Turn the eggplant and rest the slices for 20 more minutes.
steps.description: Flip the slices and let them sit for another 20 minutes, so that moisture is drawn out of the slices. Blot the eggplant slices with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Sauté the garlic with the onion and oregano for about 5 minutes.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil into a large skillet. Heat the oil over medium heat and add 3 cloves of minced garlic. Stir and sauté the garlic for 1 minute. Stir in 1 finely diced yellow onion and 2 teaspoons (2 g) of dried oregano. Sauté the mixture for about 5 minutes, so the onions soften. If you don't have dried oregano, you can use 4 teaspoons (4 g) of fresh oregano.

steps.headline: Stir in marinara sauce and season the mixture.
steps.description: Pour in 3 cups (675 g) of marinara sauce and stir until the onions are incorporated. Add salt and pepper according to your taste. Turn off the heat. You don't need to warm the sauce since it will heat up in the oven.

steps.headline: Combine the cheese filling.
steps.description: Get out a medium mixing bowl and place 16 ounces (454 g) of whole milk ricotta in it. Add 1/2 cup (50 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese, 1 large egg, and 1/4 cup (5 g) of chopped fresh parsley. Stir the cheese mixture until it's well combined. If you don't have fresh parsley, you can substitute 2 tablespoons (3 g) of dried parsley.

steps.headline: Layer the sauce, eggplant slices, cheese filling, and shredded mozzarella.
steps.description: Scoop a ladle full of marinara sauce into a large baking dish (around 9 x 13 inches or 23 x 33 cm) and spread it evenly with a spoon. Arrange a layer of eggplant slices on the sauce, so the bottom of the dish is covered. Spread half of the cheese filling across the eggplant using a spoon. Get out 4 cups (452 g) of shredded mozzarella and scatter about 1 cup (113 g) of the cheese over the cheesy filling.

steps.headline: Repeat the layers.
steps.description: Spread another ladle full of marinara over the top and arrange another layer of eggplant slices. Spread the rest of the cheese filling evenly and sprinkle another 1 cup (113 g) of the shredded mozzarella on top.

steps.headline: Finish the upper layers.
steps.description: Place a final layer of sliced eggplant in the pan and pour the rest of the marinara sauce over it. Sprinkle the last 2 cups (226 g) of shredded mozzarella over the top.

steps.headline: Bake the cheesy eggplant lasagna for 35 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and put the lasagna in the preheated oven. Bake the lasagna for 35 minutes, so the cheese becomes melted and bubbly.

steps.headline: Serve the cheesy eggplant lasagna.
steps.description: Wear oven mitts to remove the baking dish. Slice the lasagna into 12 pieces and sprinkle a little extra chopped parsley on top. Serve the lasagna while it's still hot. You can store the leftover eggplant lasagna in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 5 days. Keep in mind that the eggplant slices may become soggy the longer the lasagna is stored.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and slice the eggplants.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 375 °F (191 °C). Wash 2 large eggplants and use a sharp knife to trim off and discard 1-inch (2.5 cm) from the ends. Hold the eggplant with a steady hand and slice each into long 1/8-inch (3 mm) thick slices. 1 large eggplant weighs around 2 pounds (0.9 kg).

steps.headline: Salt and rest the eggplant slices.
steps.description: Lay the slices of eggplant in a single layer on a baking sheet. Sprinkle a large pinch of coarse salt over the eggplant slices and let them sit for 10 minutes. The salt will draw out excess moisture from the eggplant. This will prevent your lasagna from becoming soggy as it bakes. Since you're precooking the eggplant, you don't need to turn and salt the other side.

steps.headline: Heat a grill pan or skillet and blot the eggplant slices.
steps.description: Set a grill pan or large skillet (at least 12 inches or 30 cm) on the stove and turn the heat to medium. Take a paper towel and blot the eggplant slices to dry them as much as you can.

steps.headline: Cook the eggplant slices for 6 minutes.
steps.description: Lay the eggplant slices in a single layer in the hot skillet or grill pan. Cook the eggplant for 3 minutes and then flip the slices over. Cook the eggplant for another 3 minutes, so they're cooked evenly on both sides. Turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Combine the cheese filling.
steps.description: Measure 15 ounces (425 g) of part-skim ricotta into a medium mixing bowl along with 1 large egg and 1/2 cup (50 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese. Stir the mixture until the egg is incorporated. Set the filling aside.

steps.headline: Spread some tomato sauce in the baking dish and lay eggplant in the bottom.
steps.description: Get out 4 cups (900 g) of tomato sauce and pour about 1 cup (225 g) of it into the bottom of a 9 x 13-inch (22 x 33 cm) baking dish. Lay 5 or 6 eggplant slices across sauce. The bottom of the pan should be covered by a thin layer of eggplant.

steps.headline: Spread some cheese filling and shredded mozzarella over the eggplant.
steps.description: Scoop half of the cheese filling onto the eggplant slices. Use the back of a spoon to spread the filling evenly across the slices. Get out 2 cups (226 g) of shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese. Scatter a third of the shredded cheese over the cheese filling.

steps.headline: Arrange another layer of sauce, eggplant, cheese filling, and shredded cheese.
steps.description: Place another layer of eggplant slices across the cheese. Spread 1 1/2 cups (340 g) of the tomato sauce evenly over the eggplant. Spoon the remaining cheese filling over the sauce and scatter another third of the shredded cheese on top.

steps.headline: Arrange a final layer of eggplant, sauce, and shredded cheese.
steps.description: Lay the last slices of eggplant in the dish and spread the remaining 1 1/2 cups (340 g) of tomato sauce over the eggplant. Sprinkle the last third of shredded mozzarella over the top.

steps.headline: Bake the low-fat eggplant lasagna for 50 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and put it in the preheated oven. Bake the lasagna for 40 minutes. Uncover the dish and bake it for 10 more minutes.

steps.headline: Rest the lasagna for 10 minutes and serve it.
steps.description: Use oven mitts to remove the lasagna from the oven. Let it rest for 10 minutes and then slice it into 12 pieces. Sprinkle 2 tablespoons (7 g) of chopped fresh parsley over the pieces and serve them while they're hot. You can substitute 1 tablespoon (1.5 g) of dried parsley, but it won't be as bright of a garnish as the fresh parsley. You can store the leftover eggplant lasagna in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 5 days. Keep in mind that the eggplant slices may become soggy the longer the lasagna is stored.

text:
Making Cheesy Eggplant Lasagna Preheat the oven and slice the eggplants. Turn the oven on to 400 °F (204 °C). Wash 3 medium eggplants and trim off 1-inch (2.5 cm) the ends. Hold each eggplant steady with one hand and use a knife to slice long 1/4-inch (6 mm) slices. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0e\/Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg\/v4-190px-Make-Lasagna-with-Eggplant-Instead-of-Noodles-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":"190","bigHeight":"127","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} 1 medium eggplant weighs around 1 pound (453 g). Salt and rest the eggplant for 20 minutes. Lay the eggplant slices on a baking sheet in a single layer. Sprinkle a large pinch of kosher salt evenly over the slices and let the eggplant rest for 20 minutes. Salting the eggplant draws out excess moisture which will prevent your lasagna from becoming soggy as it bakes. Turn the eggplant and rest the slices for 20 more minutes. Flip the slices and let them sit for another 20 minutes, so that moisture is drawn out of the slices. Blot the eggplant slices with a paper towel. Sauté the garlic with the onion and oregano for about 5 minutes. Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil into a large skillet. Heat the oil over medium heat and add 3 cloves of minced garlic. Stir and sauté the garlic for 1 minute. Stir in 1 finely diced yellow onion and 2 teaspoons (2 g) of dried oregano. Sauté the mixture for about 5 minutes, so the onions soften. If you don't have dried oregano, you can use 4 teaspoons (4 g) of fresh oregano. Stir in marinara sauce and season the mixture. Pour in 3 cups (675 g) of marinara sauce and stir until the onions are incorporated. Add salt and pepper according to your taste. Turn off the heat. You don't need to warm the sauce since it will heat up in the oven. Combine the cheese filling. Get out a medium mixing bowl and place 16 ounces (454 g) of whole milk ricotta in it. Add 1/2 cup (50 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese, 1 large egg, and 1/4 cup (5 g) of chopped fresh parsley. Stir the cheese mixture until it's well combined. If you don't have fresh parsley, you can substitute 2 tablespoons (3 g) of dried parsley. Layer the sauce, eggplant slices, cheese filling, and shredded mozzarella. Scoop a ladle full of marinara sauce into a large baking dish (around 9 x 13 inches or 23 x 33 cm) and spread it evenly with a spoon. Arrange a layer of eggplant slices on the sauce, so the bottom of the dish is covered. Spread half of the cheese filling across the eggplant using a spoon. Get out 4 cups (452 g) of shredded mozzarella and scatter about 1 cup (113 g) of the cheese over the cheesy filling. Repeat the layers. Spread another ladle full of marinara over the top and arrange another layer of eggplant slices. Spread the rest of the cheese filling evenly and sprinkle another 1 cup (113 g) of the shredded mozzarella on top. Finish the upper layers. Place a final layer of sliced eggplant in the pan and pour the rest of the marinara sauce over it. Sprinkle the last 2 cups (226 g) of shredded mozzarella over the top. Bake the cheesy eggplant lasagna for 35 minutes. Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and put the lasagna in the preheated oven. Bake the lasagna for 35 minutes, so the cheese becomes melted and bubbly. Serve the cheesy eggplant lasagna. Wear oven mitts to remove the baking dish. Slice the lasagna into 12 pieces and sprinkle a little extra chopped parsley on top. Serve the lasagna while it's still hot. You can store the leftover eggplant lasagna in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 5 days. Keep in mind that the eggplant slices may become soggy the longer the lasagna is stored. Making Low-Fat Eggplant Lasagna Preheat the oven and slice the eggplants. Turn the oven on to 375 °F (191 °C). Wash 2 large eggplants and use a sharp knife to trim off and discard 1-inch (2.5 cm) from the ends. Hold the eggplant with a steady hand and slice each into long 1/8-inch (3 mm) thick slices. 1 large eggplant weighs around 2 pounds (0.9 kg). Salt and rest the eggplant slices. Lay the slices of eggplant in a single layer on a baking sheet. Sprinkle a large pinch of coarse salt over the eggplant slices and let them sit for 10 minutes. The salt will draw out excess moisture from the eggplant. This will prevent your lasagna from becoming soggy as it bakes. Since you're precooking the eggplant, you don't need to turn and salt the other side. Heat a grill pan or skillet and blot the eggplant slices. Set a grill pan or large skillet (at least 12 inches or 30 cm) on the stove and turn the heat to medium. Take a paper towel and blot the eggplant slices to dry them as much as you can. Cook the eggplant slices for 6 minutes. Lay the eggplant slices in a single layer in the hot skillet or grill pan. Cook the eggplant for 3 minutes and then flip the slices over. Cook the eggplant for another 3 minutes, so they're cooked evenly on both sides. Turn off the heat. Combine the cheese filling. Measure 15 ounces (425 g) of part-skim ricotta into a medium mixing bowl along with 1 large egg and 1/2 cup (50 g) of freshly grated Parmesan cheese. Stir the mixture until the egg is incorporated. Set the filling aside. Spread some tomato sauce in the baking dish and lay eggplant in the bottom. Get out 4 cups (900 g) of tomato sauce and pour about 1 cup (225 g) of it into the bottom of a 9 x 13-inch (22 x 33 cm) baking dish. Lay 5 or 6 eggplant slices across sauce. The bottom of the pan should be covered by a thin layer of eggplant. Spread some cheese filling and shredded mozzarella over the eggplant. Scoop half of the cheese filling onto the eggplant slices. Use the back of a spoon to spread the filling evenly across the slices. Get out 2 cups (226 g) of shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese. Scatter a third of the shredded cheese over the cheese filling. Arrange another layer of sauce, eggplant, cheese filling, and shredded cheese. Place another layer of eggplant slices across the cheese. Spread 1 1/2 cups (340 g) of the tomato sauce evenly over the eggplant. Spoon the remaining cheese filling over the sauce and scatter another third of the shredded cheese on top. Arrange a final layer of eggplant, sauce, and shredded cheese. Lay the last slices of eggplant in the dish and spread the remaining 1 1/2 cups (340 g) of tomato sauce over the eggplant. Sprinkle the last third of shredded mozzarella over the top. Bake the low-fat eggplant lasagna for 50 minutes. Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and put it in the preheated oven. Bake the lasagna for 40 minutes. Uncover the dish and bake it for 10 more minutes. Rest the lasagna for 10 minutes and serve it. Use oven mitts to remove the lasagna from the oven. Let it rest for 10 minutes and then slice it into 12 pieces. Sprinkle 2 tablespoons (7 g) of chopped fresh parsley over the pieces and serve them while they're hot. You can substitute 1 tablespoon (1.5 g) of dried parsley, but it won't be as bright of a garnish as the fresh parsley. You can store the leftover eggplant lasagna in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3 to 5 days. Keep in mind that the eggplant slices may become soggy the longer the lasagna is stored.
